perturbation.original_text: 8. INDEMNIFICATION 8.1 Indemnification of Indemnified Parties The Issuer shall and does hereby indemnify and save the Indemnified Parties harmless from and against any liability, claim, demand or loss, excluding loss of profits, which the Indemnified Parties may suffer, whether pursuant to statute or otherwise, howsoever arising, in consequence of: (a) any statement or omission in the Prospectus, or otherwise made or omitted by the Issuer in connection with the Offering, being or being alleged to be a misrepresentation; (b) the Issuer not complying with any requirement of applicable legislation of Canada or of British Columbia or Alberta; or (c) any order made or any inquiry, investigation or proceeding commenced, threatened or announced by any securities regulatory authority or other competent authority in British Columbia, Alberta or Ontario which prevents or restricts trading in or the sale or distribution in British Columbia and Alberta of the Securities.
perturbation.changed_text: 8. INDEMNIFICATION 8.1 Indemnification of Indemnified Parties The Issuer shall indemnify and save the Indemnified Parties harmless from any liability, claim, demand or loss, excluding loss of profits, which the Indemnified Parties may suffer in consequence of: (a) any statement or omission in the Prospectus, or otherwise made or omitted by the Issuer in connection with the Offering, being a misrepresentation; (b) the Issuer not complying with any requirement of applicable legislation of Canada or of British Columbia or Alberta; or (c) any order made or any inquiry, investigation or proceeding commenced by any securities regulatory authority or other competent authority in British Columbia, Alberta or Ontario which prevents or restricts trading in or the sale or distribution in British Columbia and Alberta of the Securities.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the phrase 'does hereby' and 'being alleged to be', the indemnification is weakened. Now it means the misrepresentation has to be proven instead of alleged, thus limiting the rights of the Indemnified Parties and potentially conflicting with securities laws that prioritize investor protection based on reasonable allegations of misrepresentation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Securities Act (British Columbia) - provisions related to due diligence and liability for misrepresentation in prospectuses.

perturbation.original_text: 8.2 Right to Counsel If any claim contemplated by this section is asserted against any of the Indemnified Parties, the Issuer shall be entitled (but not required) to assume the defence on behalf of the Indemnified Parties of any suit brought to enforce such claim, provided that the defence shall be through legal counsel acceptable to the Indemnified Parties and no admission of liability shall be made by the Issuer or the Indemnified Parties without, in each case, the prior written consent of all the parties hereto, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld. Any of the Indemnified Parties shall have the right to employ separate counsel in any such suit and participate in the defence thereof, at the expense of the Issuer.
perturbation.changed_text: 8.2 Right to Counsel If any claim contemplated by this section is asserted against any of the Indemnified Parties, the Issuer shall be entitled to assume the defence on behalf of the Indemnified Parties of any suit brought to enforce such claim, provided that the defence shall be through legal counsel acceptable to the Issuer. Any of the Indemnified Parties shall have the right to employ separate counsel in any such suit and participate in the defence thereof, at the expense of the Issuer.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'but not required', the Issuer is now REQUIRED to assume the defence. Also, the counsel has to be accepted by the Issuer, not the Indemnified Parties. It implies the Indemnified Parties have no say in who defends them. This contradicts the fundamental right of a party to choose their own legal representation in a dispute. This also undermines the Indemnified Parties ability to adequately defend their interests, thereby reducing a protection intended under Securities Law for underwriters and sponsors.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Common law principles of fairness and equity; potentially conflicting with Securities Act provisions related to due diligence and liability.

perturbation.original_text: 3.3 Survival of Representations and Warranties Each of the parties hereto acknowledges that the other parties are relying on each of the representations and warranties addressed to such other parties set forth in section 3.1 or 3.2, as the case may be, and any representations made in any certificate issued to such other parties in connection with this Agreement notwithstanding any investigations heretofore or hereafter made by such other parties or their counsel or representatives. All such representations and warranties shall not merge in or be prejudiced by, and shall survive for a period of three years from the completion of the distribution of the Units.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.3 Survival of Representations and Warranties Each of the parties hereto acknowledges that the other parties are relying on each of the representations and warranties addressed to such other parties set forth in section 3.1 or 3.2, as the case may be, and any representations made in any certificate issued to such other parties in connection with this Agreement notwithstanding any investigations heretofore or hereafter made by such other parties or their counsel or representatives. All such representations and warranties shall not merge in or be prejudiced by, and shall survive for a period of one year from the completion of the distribution of the Units.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the survival period of representations and warranties from three years to one year significantly limits the time frame within which a claim can be made for breaches of these representations. This can be problematic as some misrepresentations may not become apparent until after the first year. This reduction undermines the protections provided to investors and other parties who rely on the accuracy of the representations, potentially violating regulations designed to ensure adequate recourse for misstatements or omissions.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Securities Act (British Columbia) - provisions regarding liability for misrepresentations and the limitation periods for bringing claims related to securities offerings.
